description.text:
This is an enclosure for the Viki2 LCD, designed to be mounted against the side of a vertical surface for standing operation. It can also be mounted on a horizontal surface at a slightly different angle.

It includes holes on the back plate for mounting a DSub HD15 male jack (same as VGA). These cables work great as they have plenty of pins and are cheap and easy to work with (e.g. https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00O072K4I). The ports are available at most decent electronics shops or can be found at l-com: http://www.l-com.com/d-sub-solder-cup-d-sub-connector-hd15-male and http://www.l-com.com/d-sub-solder-cup-d-sub-connector-hd15-female

There is also a mounting hole for a 16mm "aviation" plug which you can use for chaining an additional peripheral such as a touch plate for a CNC.

The photos shown are from a prototype that didn't have front screw holes and required some tape to stay together correctly.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1843137

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=1843137

Using the following options:

HeightIfTheCircles = 1.1
scaleOfThePumpkin = 1.5
NumberOfLobes = 14
SizeOfThePumpkinSpheres = 500

Tried using a spray to lubricate the slides in your 3d printer and go it everywhere? This lubrication helper concentrates the spray on to the sliders (mainly for 8mm sliders on FFCP - can fles a little for larger sliders). It also allows easier access holding a bottle since it acts as a nozzle extension.

Print with supports only under the outside of the rod.

Doesn't Matter

Yes

There are several rear frame braces for the Anet A8 3d printer. However all put stress on the 2 screws holding the stepper motor firewall which in my opinion isn't the best approach.
The optimal setup would be to brace the stepper motor itself but I didn't like the idea because the heat from the stepper motor would not dissipate as well. I therefore decided to do the next best thing by bracing the firewall which supports the stepper motor.
The frame brace is designed so that you only need to loosen the 2 rear nuts on the middle frame support and slide it underneath. Then re-tighten the 2 nuts.
See pictures for more details.

Make sure that your slicer program is set to 100% scale. You will also need to rotate to object to make it fit on the heat bed.

Be sure to use a front brace as well e.g. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1857991

Please let me know if you have a problem with the design so I can improve it if necessary.

Also please post a picture with comments if you have made one.

Thanks.

Leo

Update 24.12.2016:
I've added a slot for the cables.

Update 21.02.2017
I've uploaded V2.0 which solves the problem of different rear frame dimensions. Users that have have modified there h-carriage mount can now also use this frame brace.

Update 26.04.2017
I've uploaded a lengthened version (+25mm) "Anet_A8_Frame_Brace_Rear_V2.0-25_Leo_N.stl" which was designed for this project: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2251940
(02.08.2017: File has been removed and is now available on the project page.)

comments.text: Just giving a heads up with my experience: V2.0 had too large of a gap both in the floor slot and in distance to the motor wall to prevent twisting of the frame. The original version (non V2.0 included in the downloaded files) fits almost perfectly. The floor gap is a tight fit on the motor wall helping preventing twisting, but the main vertical brace for the motor wall still has a paper thin gap allowing for some play/deformation in the acrylic frame. The original version of the brace also required removing some plastic as it doesn't have the nice curve of V2.0 thus crashing into the y-belt clamps. Thank you for the design, it's still a great improvement over other braces I've tried!
comments.author: ShadyPkg

comments.text:
The small floor gap is necessary because the tolerances of each built printer are too great. Too many "complaints" forced me to change the width. However the change has no negative effects. The slot could have just as well been left out as the upper support for the motor wall will prevent any major twisting.
The original version was removed from the files section some time ago.
comments.author: ShadyPkg

comments.text: Ah, I must have copied V2 into the folder of the original version. V2 seems like a no-go for my machine. At the same belt tightness, the larger gap in the floor of V2 resulted in significant twisting in the motor wall (>5 degrees) compared to the original version which was minimal (1-2 degrees at most).

description.text:
The pantograph is the original scaling tool!  It was first developed in 1603 so that Christopher Scheiner, it's inventor, could copy and scale diagrams with great precision.   Something we now do in seconds with copy machines and computers was done entirely by hand back in the days of old.  
This pantograph was created to help students explore the concept of similarity in the geometry class.  They can create 2D geometric shapes and then use the pantograph to trace their shape while watching the extendible arm draw another shape that is similar in every way (their corresponding angles are congruent and their corresponding sides are in proportion).  Help your kids explore similarity and proportionality with this wonderfully hands-on tool!

The rods were built from the ground up using SketchUp. The nut and bolt are a remix of the design posted on Thingiverse by naikrovek. To construct, follow the diagram here: http://www.ies-math.com/math/java/geo/panta/pantasetu.gif I hope you and your students enjoy! All feedback is welcomed!

3D printable micro quad frame that in my case, uses mostly Eachine QX90 hardware. It has plenty of room on board. I am using Easchine EF-01 FPV camera, 55mm propellers and 8.5x20 motors. Motors are mounted with regular rubber grommets, outside diameter 10mm and inside 8mm. Or you can use same that are used on QX90.
You can choose between two versions of top decks. The longer one holds EF-01 camera safely in place. Shorter one just gives some free space in front of quad if you use different camera. To fix top deck in place I just used four 12mm regular plastic stand-off, if 3d printed they may be little too brittle and I had them laying around, but I added file for them too, so you can print them (no thread inside, just 3mm hole).

Printer:

Colido DIY 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer

Infill:

40%

For us us budding horologist a simple and inexpensive way to polish pivots

With a few craft sticks from Wal-Mart,a glue stick, tape and sandpaper you can get your pivots polished for just a few dollars Use polish the pivot stick.cdr to create a template and then you can cut as many as you need. Then use polish the pivot paper.cdr to cut the sandpaper out to fit the sticks. Once the sticks are cut out tape the two pieces together and then use a glue stick to adhere the sandpaper to the insides of the sticks, see pics. I only spread the glue 3/4 of the way down, so that I can remove the paper once its worn out and glue a new paper in place. You can see the effect of using the system in the attached pics There is a before and after pic of an escape gear pivot. Thanks to John Tope for the idea, if you need some training be sure to check out http://www.ticktockpro.com/

description.text:
This is a collection of interlocking bug body parts. The 5 basic designs right now are

  • Ant
  • Fly
  • Praying mantis
  • Scorpion
  • Spider

But the real fun of it is that all parts are compatible with each other. You can make crazy monsters with eyes on their feet and mouths on their arms...or whatever you can imagine.

Our kids love them, and can't get enough of the colors and body parts. They are generally anatomically correct, so they are also educational!

You will need to use flexible filament such as TPU to make soft, durable bug parts. The wings, antennae, and legs won't last a minute if made from PLA. The connectors can be made from rigid material or a medium-hard such as Semiflex. These were printed with Ninjaflex and Semiflex on a Flexion Extruder. This extruder allows fast, accurate printing of flexible material.

We'll add more designs later, but feel free to come up with your own designs and add to the kit! Please link back to us so that we can print them too.

Notes:

The Flexion Extruder makes this easy to print, and allows the high-resolution required for the detailed parts.

This is a device for performing statistical experiments.
Here's a video of the operation: http://youtu.be/0tp26ChmDxA Have fun while learning about combinatorics, Pascal's triangle, probability, and the binomial distribution.
Balls are poured into the funnel and allowed to fall and collide into pegs along their journey. Ideally when a ball hits a peg head-on it has a 1/2 chance of going left or right until it finally falls into one of the bins.
The number of paths to each bin is given by C( N, x ).
N is number of rows of pegs (including the top edge of the bins) and x takes values from 0 to N (say 0 is the leftmost bin and N is the rightmost). There is a triangle overlay that shows all of these numbers and the number of paths through each intermediate peg. This also happens to be Pascal's triangle. You can lay the overlay right over the pegs but take it off when performing experiments. This particular Galton board will allow you to adjust N anywhere from 1 to 8 and so you can run experiments with as little as 2 bins or up to 9 bins. This is done by plugging the funnel into the corresponding holes aligned above the triangle of pegs.
Ideally and over the long run the number of balls in each bin will follow the binomial distribution.

This device was printed on a MakerBot Replicator 2 using PLA.
No extra parts or gluing are required.
I scaled the parts by a factor of %800. That is about a large as you can go and still fit within the print volume.
If you go smaller, you probably want to find some ball bearings instead of printing the plastic balls which are so light they tend to speed up and bounce a little to much.
In fact the device will work better with heavier balls even at full size. Build instructions:
1) Board: Print the board using rafts to try to minimize warping. Standard 0.20 mm resolution is fine (and you won't want to wait any longer).
2) Pegs: Rotate the pegs so that they lie with the flat portion on the build plate. You will need to print 28 of them. I used 0.10 mm resolution.
3) Funnel: Print the funnel upside down with the mouth of the cone on the build platform. 0.20 mm will work. No rafts, no supports required.
4) Balls: Print as many as you can! You will need to use rafts but no supports are required. Print at 0.10 resolution. IMPORTANT: make them as dense as possible. I used an infill of 75% but I would recommend 100% if you can.
5) Triangle Overlay: I printed this using rafts and at 0.15 mm resolution. Assembly:
Assembling the board is easy. Simply insert the 28 pegs into the 28 square holes that form the triangle. Leave the upper two pairs of holes empty. Those are for positioning the funnel for different experiments. The pegs actually have a slightly rounded side. Try to face that side forward. Important tip: Make sure the holes for the funnel tabs are not too tight so you don't break the tabs as you are putting the funnel in or out. You may want to sand down the funnel tabs slightly. Usage:
Plug in your funnel and drop (or pour) the balls in and what them fall into the bins making some turns along the way.
The board is already tilted but you may have to play with the tilt of the board some more. I find that tilting it up another 10 degrees or so makes it work quite well. The leftmost and lowest position of the funnel corresponds to N = 1 and the balls should only fall in the two bins below. The very top position corresponds to N = 8. When not running experiments, you can leave the triangle overlay on the board to remind people of the combinations. Enjoy!

In this project students make a stand-up display map of a country. This part of a cross-curricular "culture fair." Details of the other parts of the project can be found in the PDF file.

This is the second year of doing this project with 7th graders.
NGSS

Students create a stand-up map display of a country for a Culture Fair. This is a follow up to a project I did with the students last year. Full details of the project are in the PDF file, or look at the original project here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1108998

Steps
  • Use the Internet to find a map of their country.
    • If they find a monochrome map it can be converted into SVG using a free online image converter. Searching with terms like "clip art," "outline," "silhouette," and "black and white" will improve your chances of finding a suitable map If the map is not monochrome it can be inserted into a Google Drawing. Then use the line tools to trace the outline. After deleting the original map image the tracing can be downloaded as an SVG file.

  • Import the map SVG file in Tinkercad, make the height (z direction) at least 10 mm

  • Add a rectangular base to the map so that it will stand up when printed. Put the name of the country on the base, or on the map.

  • If the map is in several pieces (the islands of Japan, for example) connect the pieces to each other and the base with rectangular beams

  • Embellish the map by using the Text Generator or adding shapes that are symbolic or have cultural significance. Images can be imported using the same method as was used for the map

  • Double check that all parts are connected, and the height (z direction) is 10 mm or greater
    • 6.Print your model
  • Color your display with markers or paint.

title: Actobotics Rack and Pinion Linear Slide, In-Channel, 32 pitch

description.text:
Actobotics is a solid building platform with many great features. One thing it's missing is a rack and pinion linear slide mechanism that operates internal to a channel allowing one full-sized channel to slide past another one, like the mechanism offered for the Tetrix platform. This design provides such a mechanism.

Actobotics offers many good 32 pitch pinion gears, so this is a 3D printable rack to mate to a chosen Actobotics pinion gear plus sliders to hold the channel on. The rack width depends on the width of the pinion gear selected, so make sure you print the rack that corresponds to the pinion gear you'll use. STL files are provided for racks that mate with 20 tooth and 24 tooth pinion gears.

Each rack is 3" long. The racks can be used in series to provide 6", 9", 12", etc. racks.

Tested with 20T pinion gear at 9" and works smoothly.

Actobotics does provide a fixed length linear slide gear rack for beams, so it might be easier to use that rack and its associated parts if that is sufficient for your needs. But if you need full-sized channels sliding, this 3D-printable option might be useful to you. Happy building!

comments.text: Hi - we printed a few of these for use this year and we ran into some trouble. We have a mechanism so where the rack and pinion system is moving some channel with some servos on it up and down, and when we attempt to use a Neverest 40 to move the parts up, the racks start getting torn up. We used PLA to print it. What are your print configurations? Have you ever run into this issue? I'm thinking of redesigning the part to make the teeth a bit thicker and hopefully get some success, but if we can simply change our print options to fix it I would love to hear back from you.

title: Greg's Wade Accessible Belt Drive Extruder

description.text:
**I just uploaded a newer version of this design please check it out first: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456025 This is a mash-up of the Greg's Wade extruder and Terawatt Industry's belt drive extruder. It brings the zero backlash advantages of the Terawatt 00str00der design together with a heavy duty, rock solid design.
Video can be found here: http://youtu.be/cY4r6K0P9Qk
2013.12.05 Added 1.75mm filament option
2014.05.30 Corrected belt size

Components Required:
65T plastic (carbide) GT2 pulley w/8mm bore, flanges, set-screw
17T aluminum GT2 pulley w/5mm bore, flanges, set-screw
GT2 belt, 2mm pitch, 88T, 196mm length, 6mm-with, fiberglass-reinforced, closed-loop
Pulleys and belt can be sourced from stock drive products, Terawatt industries, ebay, etc.
Hobbed Bolt
608 bearings, 3 minimum (more could be used as spacers on the hobbed bolt)
2x M4 x 55 SHCS
2x springs
1x M8 axle or stud for idler pulley
4x M3 SHCS for stepper mount
4x M3 washers for stepper mount
misc other M3 / M4 hardware
Assemble as normal for Greg's style extruder. Use the slots in the stepper mount to tension the belt. Be sure to recalibrate your E steps after installation. You may also have to reverse the direction of your extruder stepper in your firmware. (I did)
Note the photos shown illustrate assembly using Terawatt Industries' elastomer bumpers for the idler tension springs. I'd highly recommend using steel springs instead, they seem to work much better.
Enjoy quieter, backlash-free printing!

comments.text: Have your ever any problem with the belt slipping on fast retractions?  I only ask to see if after 1.5yrs of use, if you have changed the pulley ratio?  Or if this combination works well.
comments.author: nitewing76

comments.text: This combination seems to work well- as far as I know, I've never experienced any belt slipping at all, under any circumstances. I'm still on the original belt, no obvious signs of wear.
comments.author: nitewing76

comments.text: This looks bloody awesome!
comments.author: Geoffro

comments.text: As you were designing this, did you ever look into using a smaller motor?  I've been wondering if maybe a NEMA 14 could provide enough torque to make this work with the right drive ratio.  It might even be possible to build a back-to-back double extruder with crossed belts.  Just thinking out loud...lots of challenges with that.
comments.author: clough42

comments.text: No, I didn't consider another motor. I would suspect a lower gear ratio would be all it would take to use a smaller stepper- the motor I'm currently using is not being worked very hard.
comments.author: clough42

comments.text:
I'm planning on giving it a try. I just got a NEMA 14 motor from Pololu yesterday and some of the belt drive parts I'll need. My math says it will work fine with a 4:1 drive ratio, supply 18Kgf to the 3mm filament and still retract at almost 30mm/s. That's all theory, though. I think the key limitation is going to be motor temperature. If I can make it work, I think it's possible to build a double extruder that weighs approximately the same as the typical single NEMA 17 designs.
In the back of my head, though, I keep hearing the voice that says if this were easy to do, someone else would already have done it.
comments.author: pefozzy

comments.text: If temperature is an issue you can always add stick-on VGA heatsinks or even cooling fans- the total weight would probably still be much less than a set of NEMA 17 motors.

comments.author: mfuqua

comments.text: Yes, you are right- I've tried a couple different versions of the extruder printed in different orientations. The initial version that I actually tested is the one with the part printed with the "side" of the extruder on the glass. After that initial version I increased the size of the bolt slots for for the stepper motor to allow for easier assembly and more adjustability.
comments.author: mfuqua

comments.text: Very nice design! I too appreciate the SLDPRT's (though I am also grateful to users who upload STP's as well). From an mechanical engineering standpoint, the direction in which the parts are printed in the first picture is correct. Since the fatigue stress of the main body during operation is horizontal, you were correct in printing the layers so they would be vertical once the part was installed. The priority should be keeping the layers perpendicular to the stresses, rather than the ease of cleaning. I'm not trying to be critical and once again I am very thankful for the SLDPRT's!!! I'm in the process of remixing this, with the only major change so far has been addition of a bolt under the stepper for extra stability.
comments.author: pefozzy

comments.text:
Constructive feedback is always appreciated!
One thing on the design that I need to get around to fixing is the wall thickness between the hobbed bolt bearings and outside of the part (facing the idler wheel) is too thin. I've had this start to fail on my personal printer after many, many hours of printing. When I have time I'll increase this wall thickness as well as add quick-release idler bolts.

Is your iPhone simply too heavy to carry? Do you wish you had an easier way to bring it out into the world with you?
The wheeliebot is a wheeled iPhone case with a handle attachment! Now you can travel the world with your phone by your side!

The wheelieBot is designed from the ground up to allow iPhones to become more portable. No longer will you have to leave it at home when you go out! After printing I reamed out the axle holes, sanded the shaft slightly and attached the two ends of the axles to each other with a piece of wire. Zip tie a broom handle on to the back and you are ready to go see the world! The openscad file is a little rough. You need to comment out the individual parts in order to export the stls. I uploaded the stl files as well. I took pains to make this a printible piece, as I was disappointed by the sheer number of EvD entries that are unprintible, and wouldn't even work if they could be printed. Check out the commercial here
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uNixGHr-994
This product is a parody, and is intended for the Engineer vs designer absurd iPhone contest. Save your breath if you want to tell me it is absurd. Or better yet, tell the fine folks over at EvD!

remixed_from.author: 13DjjC13
remixed_from.title: Sunhokey Acrylic Prusa I3 X Axis Carriage

title: Sunhokey Replacement X-Carriage with E3D Mount

description.text:
This is a complete rework of the carriage assembly for the Sunhokey Prusa i3 2015 model. Might be usable on other Prusa clones too.

This is a mashup with Tech2C's E3D mount and 13DjjC13's x carriage along with my own modifications. I did all the modifications within 3dsmax. The main things here I did was made it so I could mount Tech2C's mount to 13DjjC13's carriage. Along with that, I made the following changes to Tech2C's excellent mount.

  • I added a bracket to support the cooling fan for the hotend-heatsink.
  • Utilizing the added 40mm heatsink fan, I added a bracket where you can attach a LED light.
  • I modified the E3D clamp slightly, and added an additional piece to guide the wires.
  • I adjusted the z-probe to use a set screw instead of the traditional nuts, which aren't suited for quick adjustments and can rattle loose.
  • I made the fan duct adjustable, and made other tweaks to help point the airflow directly under the tip.
  • I adjusted the model to fit a 40mm turbo fan. (Now, I know a 50mm is more traditional for turbofans, but what I happened to have was a 40mm fan. So, I may make a variation for a 50mm if I get my hands on one.)

It seems like the outermost connecting point is obstructed by the bracket holding the extruder in place. description.text:
If you have a Tronxy X3 you might find these designs useful if you haven't already modified the printer. I decided I wanted some end caps for the 2020 extrusion to give it a cleaner look and smoother edges. Also I wanted a more versatile hotend shroud so I made my own with a mount for a 25mm fan for cooling the filament. There is a modified X axis endstop bracket as I did not like the original. Also I designed a replacement for the Belt pully brackets that were made out acrylic as my x axis bracket split under the constant tension.
For a more indepth on these components you can see my Youtube video in the link below

Update: I added a few items for anyone with a little bit of 2020 extrusion lying around and you want to put legs on your X3. Check out the photos. This enables me to have the electronics box site under the printer taking up much less space

comments.text: The only time I have one of the threaded rods go out of alignment with the other is if I am working on the printer and it has only happened twice in the last 7 weeks. I have this printer print almost 24/7 for me and do not have this issue. I may be one of the lucky ones however as I know quality control is poor with tronxy. The only ting I can think of for a stabilizer would be to print a toothed gear compatible with gt2 belt for the top of each rod. affix them with a set screw and connect a belt so that no matter how much one belt turns the other always turns the same amount even when steppers are not engaged

comments.text: Have you tried swapping the two rods to see if the problem transfers to the other stepper motor, if it does then your assumption is right and your rod is the problem, if it does not then you have eliminated the rod out of the equation of what the possible cause may be

title: Updated RAMPS 1.4 case for Taurino and RAMPS 1.4 shield

description.text: This is an update of an Arduino case that I use to hold a Taurino board with a RAMPS 1.4 shield. The stepper and sensor wires go in through the top of the case and the power and USB connectors in the end. There is a space at the end of the case for a 40mm fan that can be driven off the Arduino power connectors. I didn't put in any openings for the LCD controller or SD card.

comments.text: I like the look very much.  From experience, I think the walls are way too thick.  You can get away with much thinner walls, without sacrificing protection.  Not to mention the print time will be drastically reduced.  1.4mm thick walls are ideal if you print using 0.5mm nozzle.
comments.author: wildseyed

comments.text: I rather have thick walls. If I am to bother with a case, it should protect in transport as well.
comments.author: wildseyed

comments.text: This was one of the first things that I did, and I wondered about wall thickness, but I erred on the side of caution and precedent. Thinner walls should be easy, as long as the screw bases remain sturdy.
comments.author: wildseyed

comments.text: can u describe how to hook a fan to the arduino mega plz? thnks
comments.author: mrPrik

comments.text: The RAMPS board has three connectors for fine control of 12 VDC.  These are for the extruder, heated bed, and a fan used to cool plastic/hot-end insulator when printing with PLA.  These are labeled D8, D9, and D10.  DON'T use these.
comments.author: mrPrik

comments.text: Thanks for the suggestion. When I went looking for info there were mentions of connecting a fan to AUX, but there was an reply that suggested that a plugging anything into aux was a bad idea. Since I was unfamiliar with all the commenters I decided to use what seemed to be the largest power supply and set it up to turn the fan on all the time. The next time I mess with it, I'll try the 12V-AUX that I see by the X stepper connector.
comments.author: wildseyed

comments.text: Sorry, I haven't done anything specific with the Arduino board. I just wired the fan to the D9(extruder 2 heater) screws on the RAMPS shield.
comments.author: mrPrik

remixed_from.title: Timing Belt Y MXL, Printrbot Simple V2

title: PrintrBot Simple Y-Axis Belt Conversion - Modified Bearing Mount

description.text:
This is a modification of one of the parts from iamjonlawrence's brilliant Y-axis conversion (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:180146) to toothed belt for the PrintrBot Simple. He had a problem that, when he really tightened the belt, the bearing pillars weren't up to the strain.
He's designing a part for the tops of the bearings to help, but I thought there was a bit too much hollow space in the pillars. So, I just filled them in a bit.
This design is untested, and will take longer screws than the original, but I have confidence that it will hold up. I have hardware coming this week, and will report back.
EDIT: I did a dry assembly with just some 20mm M3 screws, and I did notice that the screws will have to be JUST the right length. If they extend past the nuts, they will be digging into wood and putting torque on the part.
EDIT: I went ahead and designed a top brace that also acts as a shim for extra length of your screws (edit thickness in OpenSCAD).
EDIT: Added a version with enough clearance for a nylock nut. This is the version I have on my PrintrBot Simple, and it's working like a champ.
EDIT: If you own a Simple, you should REALLY check out iamjonlawrence's profile! He's developed a BUNCH of great mods to improve the Simple.

I printed in PLA, 0.2mm layers, 30% infill, with support (for the nut captures in the base; I haven't got the hang of bridges yet), fan on as always for PLA.
Since the nut is at the very base, if the screw extends past the nut, you will have to either grind the end of the screw to fit, or drill relief holes in the PrintrBot Y arm (use the part as a template).
EDIT: You can use the top brace as a shim and brace. You can edit in OpenSCAD for 1mm or more. I have included STL files for 1.0, 1.5, and 2.0mm.

title: MULTI-Module JR style Tx Case Taranis Flysky th9x multiprotocol

description.text:
MULTI-Module case.

This is a module case for the MULTI Transmitter Module that supports more than 40 different RC transmitter protocols. It has been designed specifically for the FrSky Taranis and the FlySky TH9x Turnigy 9X transmitters. The internal mounting points have been specifically customized to house the Banggood 4-in-1 Transmitter module. Access the AVR-ISP programming header is through the hole covered by the black TPU plug. Watch out for remixes of this case costomized for other module options. (See https://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2165676 for more details or the github page for documentation https://github.com/pascallanger/DIY-Multiprotocol-TX-Module)

Instructions:

Print the Case and the Cover in PLA or ABS
Insert 15mm long pieces of clear filament through the led holes and glue in place to create "fiber optic" status leds. Ensure that the end of the fiber close to the leds is cleanly cut of optimal transmission.
Print the Plug in TPU or Ninjaflex
You will need 7 M2x6 self tapping screws to assemble.

description.text:
This print is for mounting an electronic altimeter/tracker in the nosecone of a high powered rocket. The rocket airframe is 3" in diameter. The base of the nosecone is necessary for recovery harness attachment and is mounted to the nosecone itself with screws to a bonded internal ring. The altimeter/tracker mount must be small enough to pass through this ring and allow for full extension of the antenna tuned for the 70cm Ham band.

The altimeter used in this case is Altus/Metrum, The red button at the base of the mount is a push on / push off switch. The switch is inserted in a cutout specifically crafted for it. The altimeter is attached with screws into brass inserts in the ABS print (obtained from McMaster-Carr). Below the altimeter is a bay for a 1200mAH battery which is sufficient to keep the tracking function working and transmitting coordinates for over 12 hours. The antenna is taped to a 5/16" dowel inserted into the end of the mount.

The bay should be printed laying on the print bed as shown, not standing on end, so that the weaker extrusion lines are not on the cross section of the print. This gives maximum strength during violent launch and chute deployment.

This was used in a recent launch at BALLS 2016 and provided excellent tracking of the rocket through launch and descent. The rocket was recovered nearly 8 miles away and we continued receiving transmissions throughout the recovery.

This print is the second iteration of the design providing better strength for the antenna dowel mount as it broke off during flight, probably at drogue chute ejection which saw a very large impulse due to a likely excess black powder ejection charge.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

30% for strength

Notes:

the original design was printed standing on end, which did not provide enough lateral strength between layers such that the antenna mount broke free. The design is now strengthened, but I would recommend printing it horizontally with 45 degree supports underneath for much better lateral shear strength.
123D Design

title: Vertical and Horizontal Alignment Laser Bracket for generic Chinese 50W laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I work at The Forge Makerspace in Greensboro, NC. I'm one of the heads of the laser cutter department. Our 50W laser has a red reference laser which can be quite helpful, but it left a bit to be desired, especially when we put a metal honeycomb under the workpiece. It can be really hard to determine if the workpiece is aligned to right angles which can sometimes be a big problem.

I developed this bracket which holds two "Red Line Laser Module 5mW 650nm Focus Adjustable Laser Head 5V Industrial Grade" which I ordered from ebay. (http://www.ebay.com/itm/281725342189) The bracket is made to guarantee that the centers of the two line lasers are exactly perpendicular to the shaft which houses the lens of the cutting laser. The bracket itself is kept square by slotting into the metal bracket to which the cutting head is anchored. Once you get the lasers focussed and adjusted (I used a bit of hot glue to immobilize the lenses once I got them into focus) then the lines should meet at the point where the cutting laser hits. Even better, if you leave the existing spot reference laser in addition to these new lasers, you should be able to determine that you're at the correct focus depth by seeing when the spot meets the crosshairs.

In addition to printing the bracket, you will need two of the red line laser modules I referenced above which will need to be spliced into the same wire that powers the spot reference laser. You will also need two screws and two nuts. Either 4-40 or M3 should work with this design.

title: Prusa i3 mk1 upgraded spool holder

description.text: I found that the standard filament holder for the prusa i3 mark 1 and mark 2 were sub-par as it was very annoying to change rolls of filament and did not fit all of the rolls of filament that I have owned. I simply improved upon the original design by replacing the knobs used to hold the filament with a pocket, and created a long rod out of a cylinder that was the same dimensions as the knob. This allows for you to place the two arms on your printer permanently, and simply to lift up on the rod to replace the roll(s) of filament. The design also allows you to fit two standard 1kg rolls of filament or 3-4 rolls of .5 kg filament but I am not certain because I do not own any rolls of that size. Hopefully this design saves you some frustration and provides you with easy roll replacement. Also the stl file linked does not have the parts connected as shown in the third picture, they are arranged in a way so that when you have your brim activated, the rod is securely held to the printbed

A simple rope holder spool for small lengths of rope. Scale up or down as required. Posted stl file has a total size of 200mm x 64mm with the inner portion that holds the rope at 104mm x 32mm. (see image)

This is my own design of an open assistive technology device which allows people with missing digits and/or reduced digital dexterity or grip strength to insert and turn keys in locks.

For people with arthritis this device can be operated with little to no grip strength.

For people with missing digits and/or reduced digital dexterity this device can be operated with a minimum of one finger and can accommodate a maximum of three fingers in the device but you can obviously use you whole hand if you want.

The device can fit comfortably in a pocket and with the fluorescent color it lends itself to easy identification even in low light settings.

In addition to the 3-d print, I use one 4mm bolt, two 4mm nuts and one 4mm washer to secure a wide variety of keys within the recessed area of the device. Behind the handle of the key is a short slot which allows for keys with varying handle sizes and handle hole locations. With a small modification a key loop can be added so that it can be attached to a traditional lanyard or keychain.

I have personally tested this device as of 26 Oct 2016 and it works quite well if I do say so myself.

title: Loose Filament Spool Holder (for Filament Samples)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I tend to purchase or otherwise acquire a lot of filament samples that seem to come without any type of spool. There are a lot of spool holders available but I was looking for something specific, not sure why. This is my first attempt and I may revise it.

Loose spools are a pain and either tangle or just plain can't be used because I need them to sit on a spool holder the way my printers are configured in my environment.

With my version there are tabs in the front that you can simply rotate to allow easy insertion & removal of the loose filament coil. Just rotate the tabs towards the center, slide the coil on the three pegs, then rotate the tabs back to their original position.

The center spool size is 55mm and the outer pegs are intended for about a 140mm coil. This is sized to fit a bunch of Algix3D loose filament coils I have right now. If anyone needs different dimensions let me know.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

50%

Notes:

There are two versions of the main spool holder. I have not printed the one with all of the holes but made it to cut down on the amount of filament required after printing the one with the solid center spool. It should work.

You will need to print three of the tabs and they will simply press into the holes. It may take a tiny bit of force to get them to go in but once inserted they should rotate easily and not come out (without force).

50% infill worked fine for me but adjust as you see fit.

title: A Mini Merry Marblevator Christmas Tree

description.text:
Yes, I know, I'm just as bad as the box stores as I am already designing, printing and publishing Christmas things even before Halloween.

A Mini Merry Marblevator Christmas Tree is a smaller version of this thing "http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:598343". Only four printed parts ("Track.stl", "Auger.stl", "Cap.stl" and "Star.stl") are required for a functional "A Mini Merry Marblevator Christmas Tree", additional parts will be forthcoming for "ornaments" if desired.

Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UsCQIRXqm_c. The next video show a prototype running at various speeds from 1.5vdc through 6.0vdc: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=99CamFug-yE. Final video speed test with Angel top: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z_C7dn4Jbk0.

Designed using Sketchup Make 2016, sliced with Cura, and printed on an Ultimaker 2 Extended (waiting for the Ultimaker 3!!!).

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

For the parts "Track.stl" and "Auger.stl" I used the Cura brim setting.

For the part "Star.stl" I used the Cura supports setting.

Parts I Purchased:

1) Gear Motor: DC 6V 60 RPM High Torque Electric Replacement Gear Box Motor (Amazon).

2) Coaxial Power Jack: Coaxial (Radio Shack part number 274-1583).

3) Power Supply: 6VDC (Radio Shack 273-315).

4) 8mm ball bearings (local hardware store, Amazon).

Printing:

Print one each of all parts. When printing "Track.stl" and "Auger.stl" I used the Cura brim setting. When printing "Star.stl" I used the Cura supports setting.

Assembly:

Prior to assembly, test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required. If the tight fitting components are too loose, add a small dot of cyanoacrylate to each side of the pin, allow to dry completely (I use accelerator to speed the process), then try the fit again. Repeat until tight.

Assemble as per "Assembly.stl". I perform the assembly task in the following order:

1) Carefully remove the brim from the components printed with the brim setting and supports for the component printed with the support setting. Also carefully clean the entry and exit holes in "Track.stl" making sure the 8mm ball bearing easily enters these holes.

2) Slide "Auger.stl" into the larger tube of "Track.stl", making sure it rotates freely. If not, using "Auger.stl", ream the hole until it does. When fully seated in "Track.stl", notice the vertical position of "Auger.stl for the next step.

3) Press the gear motor into position. Make sure the gear motor shaft aligns with the hole in "Auger.stl", then press together such that the motor shaft enters the hole in the bottom of "Auger.stl". The motor shaft must extend into the hole in the bottom of "Auger.stl", and "Auger.stl" must be vertically positioned in "Track.stl" as noted in the previous step.

4) Press "Cap.stl" onto the top of "Track.stl".

5) Press "Star.stl" onto the top of "Auger.stl".

6) Wire the motor such that "Star.stl" rotates clockwise when viewed from the top of the assembly.

7) Test the mechanism by adding the ball bearings to the track and plugging it in. The ball bearings should enter the lower hole and exit the upper hole with ease. If any jamming, hesitancy, etc. is observed, use a modeling knife to slightly enlarge the holes, while being careful not to leave any trimmed plastic strands. Test again and repeat if necessary.

Enjoy!

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hqSj5lPa6RC

Here's a CNC-machined crib board design that I made several years back. Finished length is 13.25", width is 4", height is 0.625".

I made mine out of a 14" x 4" x 0.75" chunk of 6061-T6 aluminum bar stock, machining was done top-down in a single setup.

List of machine tools you'll need:

  • Suitable end mill to square off the ends and set the overall 13.25" length.
  • Face mill / fly cutter to level and clean up the top surface.
  • 3/8" (or smaller) flat nose end mill to cut around the raised track.
  • 1/8" drill for the holes.
  • 45 degree chamfer bit to finish the holes**
  • 1/32" end mill for the track slots and skunk marker.
  • 3/8" diameter ball end mill for the inverse fillet around edge of board***

** Optional but recommended. The STL file doesn't have the countersinking in it so you'll have to add it yourself using your CAM software. Use a 1/64", 45 degree chamfer on the hole edges.

*** Or do lots of passes with a flat end mill, bull nose end mill or whatever you've got. If you're using CAM software and operating a CNC machining center, you know what you're doing :)

For pegs, I'm using Lee Valley part numbers 41K05.01 (brass) 41K05.02 (black) and 41K05.03 (nickel). I highly recommend using metal pegs, because extracting broken wooden or plastic pegs out of the board is guaranteed to be a bitch. Peg diameter should be 1/4" (the hole spacing used on this board) or less.

You'll also want a half dozen adhesive rubber feet to stick to the bottom surface of the board when it's done, to keep it in place and keep it from marking up whatever you lay it on. I'm using Lee Valley part # 00S20.08.

description.text:
This is a set of metric spanners that can be printed out.
The original Alibre Design files are attached. By modifying the parameters you can create any size you desire.
  • light duty = thin, solid tools
  • medium duty = thick, hollow tools
  • heavy duty = thick, solid tools
    • details:
  • rounded edges where the hand may touch
  • slanted edges for the nut
  • size is +0.1mm (M8=8.1mm side length)

The STL are checked with Netfabb and should be fine.
  • I uploaded repaired versions of the medium-duty variants
  • When exporting your own from Alibre, run Netfabb on it with auto-fixing and then "close all holes". This solves an issue betwen these STL and Skeinforge 2010-02-12 .

comments.text: Hi. What size wire did you use for your moxon? This is the third one Im downloading because the other 2 where pretty far off of the dimensions calculated.
comments.author: Lelliott

comments.text: The MoxGen program assumes free air space, so when using support material we determined that the numbers were around 7% off of theoretical dimensions.
comments.author: Lelliott

comments.text: Why use a Moxon as opposed to a Monopole?
comments.author: SelfMadeDiesl

comments.text: The Moxon is a directional antenna, basically a 2 element Yagi.  It has increased gain to the front of the antenna so It will give you longer range than a dipole.  The Moxon has pretty good coverage to the sides, unlike a Yagi, so there is not as much worry about being pointed in precisely the correct direction.

remixed_from.author: BlamJam
remixed_from.title: Underslung Power Supply Mount for Vision Prusa Mendel Printers

title: Undercarriage power supply holder for Vision printer

description.text: I didn't like having the power supply hanging off on the side of my printer.  I wanted to mount it under the printer and saw BlamJam's version.  Unfortunately because I had installed the fan duct, his version wouldn't work for me.  I had to redesign the whole thing from scratch.

If you have a Vision printer, you will need to elevate  your printer by a little bit.  I created a set of printer stands that do just that and also covers the LED strips on the base of the printer.  You will need four 15mm long M3 capscrews.  You may also have to enlarge the screw holes a little.  My original thought was to use nuts with the screws.  My brother looked at it and realized that if the hole was a little undersized, the screw would cut threads into the plastic and hold it together.  
I have not gone back and enlarged the holes yet in the original file.  I need to reprint this anyway so I'll fix it then and upload the file.  Enlarge the holes in the outer tabs with a drill so the screw passes freely through it and bites into the holes of the inner tabs.  You don't have to make it tight, the tolerance is pretty tight so the tabs will grab onto the threaded rods even without the screws.

author: NightPueo

title: E3D v5 Fan Shroud for Delta Mini Kossel Effector with Z probe

description.text:
My filament was constantly jamming due to the filament being too hot in the heat sink, which was resolved by (1) lower print temperature and (2) better cooling for the heat sink.

I made this fan shroud to help improve #2.

The part that slots into the heat sink is tight enough and strong enough to hold the whole assembly on; however, you can additionally use an M3x15 or M3x20 bolt/nut, with the bolt coming from the inside of the fan out and the nut on the back of the shroud.

You may need to take off the fan first, put the shroud on, put the entire assembly back onto the printer, and then screw in the fan.

This elevates the Vision printer so the power supply can be mounted under it.  It also covers the LED strips.  You need to install the LED strips and the foam cushion with this to have enough clearance to mount the power supply under it using my power supply bracket.

Because my print bed is 200mm x 200mm, I could not print the stand in one piece.  So you will have to print four of them, two for each side.  It is long enough to cover the full length of the LED strips.  
Mount the LED strips to the printer, stick the foam strips in the channels of the stands, then stick it to the bottom of the printer.  You could use double stick tape between the LED strips and the foam, but it seems to hold itself in place nicely without it.

title: Spare parts for DJI Phantom SARbox add ons

description.text:
Spare parts for:
SARbox add ons & Drop and delivery device.

The SARbox is a cool little box designed for DJI Phantom 3 but can work with any rc vehicle or even on a wall and you can activate it ONLY by light!
On the Phantom 3 & 4 - you can control the front led lights of the drone from your remote control (with C1/C2 buttons).

This SARbox converts that light into a channel or a power switch that can be used for many purposes in search & rescue mission, drone fishing and also for general filming where you need extra lights or an extra fpv.

You can make use of the parts here or you can design your own mechanism to do whatever you want with the SARbox or just to print it in different colours/material or small modifications to fit your purposes.

For more information on the SARbox and drop delivery device:
http://www.gimbal-guard.com/sarbox
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=emjhu5VeBDI
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IPSNovwQZQ8
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o9n3s3hEPiA
https://youtu.be/HakuQDHCZlQ?t=22m11s

You can also get it on ebay:
SARbox for P3:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/SARbox-for-dji-Phantom-3-for-use-in-search-rescue-drone-fishing-photography-/291870672353?hash=item43f4d905e1:g:UqUAAOSwknJX1E81

SARbox for P4:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/SARbox-for-dji-Phantom-4-for-use-in-search-rescue-drone-fishing-photography-/302068743825?hash=item4654b33e91:g:UqUAAOSwknJX1E81

Drop and Delivery device:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/Extra-channel-receiver-for-DJI-Phantom-3-4-to-activate-servo-/302045722640?ssPageName=STRK:MESE:IT

comments.text: Hi.  I am the creator of Project Ryptide, and I am working on a collaborative project with SWARM to develop open source tools to offer SAR tools that be printed and adapted to drones for specific emergency responses.    SWARM is run by Jim Bowers, and has >8000 Member volunteers.  During Hurricane IRMA, SWARM mobilized  more than 600 drone volunteers to help provide damage assessment that was used by the emergency response management in South Florida.

title: Aus3D IR Z Probe Parametric Bracket

description.text:
This is a customisable adaptor / bracket that can be used to attach the Aus3D IR Z probe to various mounting holes.

The IR Probe is designed to attach directly to the 30mm fan on E3D HotEnds, requiring no mounting bracket. However, a bracket may be necessary with other HotEnds or mounting configurations.

This bracket can be used to suit mounting the probe to different sizes of HotEnd fans, at varying Z-offsets from the nozzle.

A range of common values have been generated from the OpenSCAD file and are included. Other brackets can be generated either by downloading and using the source file, or by using the Thingiverse Customizer.

title: Modular Spool Holder V2 for 2080 V-Slot extrusion
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
TEVO Black Widow : Spool Holder for 2080 V-slot extrusion with bearing wheels

Note : Do not hesitate to leave me a little tip if you like the design. That helps me to pay the filament I waste when I print prototypes.

What to print :

  • 1 of each foot
  • 2 sliding NUT per foot
  • 2 Rings
  • 2 Holders (whatever version or size)

There are 2 versions of the holder, declined in 2 sizes (76 & 100m) :

  • V2 : to be used with standard hexagonal-head bolts
  • V3 : to be used with a threaded rod all along.

Additional hardware :

To assemble the holder V2 :

  • 2 M4 20mm bolts
  • 2 M4 Nylon nuts

To assemble the holder V3 :

  • 4 M3 12mm bolts
  • 4 M3 Nylon nuts

To fix the holder to the feet :

  • 2 8x22x7 wearing wheels (608ZZ)
  • 2 M8 35mm Hexagonal-head bolts
  • 2 M8 nuts
  • 2 M8 washers

To fix the whole stuff to the extrusion :

  • 2 M4 10mm bolts
  • 2 printed "sliding-Nuts"

For Intermediate foot :

  • 1 M8 50mm Hexagonal-head bolts
  • 1 M8 nut

Release Notes :

  • 2017-02-20 : Added a "no-bearing" version of the holder, designed by Jari Tulilahti (http://www.thingiverse.com/jartza/about)
  • 2017-01-25 : Added a version for 2060 Vslot extrusion
  • 2016-11-03 : Added a "straight" version. New version of feet to use a printed "sliding nut" (to ease the move across the extrusion). Added a cylinder version for people who want to use a long threaded rod.
  • 2016-10-27 : First release

Printer:

TEVO Black Widow

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

20% is enough

Notes:

Supports can be added for the holders but aren't mandatory. It depends on your machine's skills.

title: large octagon bubble bubbler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Good Day, Today I bring to you a Large octagon bubbler with a ice catcher. the design is 123mmx8mmx189mm. The design is 3d printable and I recommend using Slic3r because some other programs skip layers . Good luck. For more info take a look at GOOD DAY.txt

NEVER LIGHT PLASTIC ON FIRE, THE POISONUS FUMES ARE DEADLY, use a glass bowl or attachment. I do not condone under age smoking,

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200-300 microns (.2mm-.3mm)

Infill:

100% rectilinear (is a must)

Notes:

Before printing the bubbler I highly suggest checking your printer calibration with 18mm.stl and comparing it with comparison.jpg. 100% rectilinear infill is a must and requires about 210gms of filament.
